citing_paper_authors: Ryo, Nagata | Atsuo, Kawai | Koichiro, Morihiro | Naoki, Isu
raw_text: For in stance, Chodorow and Leacock (2000) point out that the word concentrate is usually used as a noun in a general corpus whereas it is a verb 91% of the time in essays written by non-native learners of English
clean_text: For instance, Chodorow and Leacock (2000) point out that the word concentrate is usually used as a noun in a general corpus whereas it is a verb 91% of the time in essays written by non-native learners of English.

citing_paper_authors: Rachele, De Felice | Stephen G., Pulman
raw_text: With this in mind, all we can do is mention some work which we feel is closest in spirit to our approach, but stress that the figures are for reference only, and can not be com pared directly to ours. Chodorow and Leacock (2000) try to identify errors on the basis of context, as we do here, and more specifically a? 2 word window around the word of interest, from which they consider function words and POS tags
clean_text: Chodorow and Leacock (2000) try to identify errors on the basis of context, as we do here, and more specifically a 2 word window around the word of interest, from which they consider function words and POS tags.

citing_paper_authors: Joachim, Wagner | Jennifer, Foster | Josef, van Genabith
raw_text: N-gram-based approaches to the problem of error detection have been proposed and implemented in various forms by Atwell (1987), Bigert and Knutsson (2002), and Chodorow and Leacock (2000) amongst others
clean_text: N-gram-based approaches to the problem of error detection have been proposed and implemented in various forms by Atwell (1987), Bigert and Knutsson (2002), and Chodorow and Leacock (2000) amongst others.

citing_paper_authors: Joachim, Wagner | Jennifer, Foster | Josef, van Genabith
raw_text: Furthermore, n-grams crossing clause boundaries are not flagged and the similarity measure is adapted in the case of phrase boundaries that usually result in low frequency n-grams. Chodorow and Leacock (2000) use a mutual information measure in addition to raw frequency of n grams
clean_text: Chodorow and Leacock (2000) use a mutual information measure in addition to raw frequency of n grams.

raw_text: Amongun supervised checkers, Chodorow and Leacock (2000) exploits negative evidence from edited textual corpora achieving high precision but low re call, while Tsao and Wible (2009) uses general corpus only
clean_text: Among unsupervised checkers, Chodorow and Leacock (2000) exploits negative evidence from edited textual corpora achieving high precision but low recall, while Tsao and Wible (2009) uses general corpus only.

raw_text: For example, Chodorow and Leacock (2000) exploit bi grams and trigrams of function words and part of-speech (PoS) tags, while Sun et al (2007) use labeled sequential patterns of function, time expression, and part-of-speech tags
clean_text: For example, Chodorow and Leacock (2000) exploit bigrams and trigrams of function words and part-of-speech (PoS) tags, while Sun et al (2007) use labeled sequential patterns of function, time expression, and part-of-speech tags.

raw_text: For example, unsupervised systems of (Chodorow and Leacock, 2000) and (Tsao and Wible, 2009) leverage word distributions in general and/or word-specific corpus for detecting erroneous usages while (Hermet et al, 2008) and (Gamon and Leacock, 2010) use Web as a corpus
clean_text: For example, unsupervised systems of (Chodorow and Leacock, 2000) and (Tsao and Wible, 2009) leverage word distributions in general and/or word-specific corpus for detecting erroneous usages while (Hermet et al, 2008) and (Gamon and Leacock, 2010) use Web as a corpus.

raw_text: Chodorow and Leacock (2000) utilized mutual information and chi-square statistics to identify typical contexts for a small set of targeted words from a large well-formed corpus
clean_text: Chodorow and Leacock (2000) utilized mutual information and chi-square statistics to identify typical contexts for a small set of targeted words from a large well-formed corpus.

citing_paper_authors: Joel R., Tetreault | Michael, Heilman | Aoife, Cahill
raw_text: 3.2.1 Filter-based system The filter-based system combines unsupervised detection of a set of possible errors (Chodorow and Leacock, 2000) with hand-crafted filters designed to reduce this set to the largest subset of correctly flagged errors and the smallest possible number of false positives
clean_text: The filter-based system combines unsupervised detection of a set of possible errors (Chodorow and Leacock, 2000) with hand-crafted filters designed to reduce this set to the largest subset of correctly flagged errors and the smallest possible number of false positives.

citing_paper_authors: Joel R., Tetreault | Michael, Heilman | Aoife, Cahill
raw_text: Chodorow and Leacock (2000) found that low-frequency bi grams (sequences of two lexical categories with a negative log-likelihood) are quite reliable predictors of grammatical errors
clean_text: Chodorow and Leacock (2000) found that low-frequency bigrams (sequences of two lexical categories with a negative log-likelihood) are quite reliable predictors of grammatical errors.
